reviewText: Struggling through the Depression years of the 1930s, Charley Appleby (Fred MacMurray) is a mserly storekeeperwhose idea of music is the sound of his cash register's bell. Then, abruptly, a series of near-fatal accidents, visitations from a novice angel (Harry Morgan of TV's M*A*S*H), and a run-in with bootlegging gansters help Charley gain a heartwarming - and hilarious - new outlook on life! Academy Award-winning actress Cloris Leachman and Kurt Russell add to the fun in this whimsical Disney romp.
summary: Charley And The Angel Is Great

reviewText: look. it's been too long. this film is obviously being neglected by Disney for some absurd reason. if the current Disney company wants anyone to believe they understand their origins and the original Burbank studio films they will not continue to neglect and ignore this film.i mean this was Fred MacMurray's last film for Disney and that without a doubt means something in Disney history. or has the company forgotten what an asset MacMurray was in the fledgling days of the Disney live-action films?some Disney films may seem obscure to those today, but to those of us that were there while Walt was still alive, and who never missed a single studio release, these films made a strong impression.i think Disney needs to hire a true Disney fan on their staff who grew up watching these wonderful little films like a lot of us did. maybe then would the older live-action films get better treatment.james johnston (the Alice fan)
summary: Would Disney PLEASE Re-Release This Classic On DVD!!!!

reviewText: I vaguely remember seeing this when it was first released.  Turns out, that's not the same thing as fondly remembering it.  The plot is standard fare, that old gambit about second chances.  A grumpy hardware store owner (Fred MacMurray as Charley Appleby), is made to see the error of his ways by a secular version of an angel (Harry Morgan).  There are a number of near misses before Charley is told his number is up (quaint terminology for death is a-knockin').  At this point, is the angel a messenger or the grim reaper?  Considering the sheer number of visitations, I'd say he was trying to hound poor Appleby to death.  From start to last, this is lightweight comedy at best, ordinary melodrama at worst.  Everything about this tepid offering is lackluster, even the dingy FX used to materialize the angel or send him off in a series of twinkling cartoony stars.  Of the cast, only Cloris Leachman does anything of merit with the anemic material (she was nominated for a Golden Globe for best actress for this role).  She's the only reason I bought this movie but it's not enough of a reason for me to keep it for future viewings.  It's an undistinguished film poorly preserved.

reviewText: Set in the Great Depression, "Charley and the Angel" is a warm-hearted, tender tale that boasts adventure and romance.  A workaholic general store owner receives a visit from up above and must reprioritize his life:  an eloping daughter, two would-be-bootlegging sons, and a romantic wife who wants nothing more than to visit the World Fair all call Charley back to earth!I am so glad I found this rare Disney treasure!
Title: N/A

reviewText: 'Charley and the Angel' is one of my favorite Disney live action films from the original Burbank studio. it was Fred MacMurray's last film for Disney and also his best in my opinion. Disney fans always love 'Shaggy Dog' and 'Absent Minded Professor', and i really love those movies too, but it's 'Charley' that really moves and intrigues me. not to mention there are some very good history lessons here about the 1930's depression era in which this is happening.there are some really good performances and the kids are among Disney's funniest portrayals of children they've ever done.the only problem was the DVD transfer from film. it was awful. i don't always object to some use of pan and scan to make a movie work for full screen presentation, but this whole film was pan and scan on almost every other scene. it was terrible. the color was also faded and washed out and the audio was weird and fuzzy. i can't believe Disney put this out like this in the first place.if you choose to purchase this DVD, poor quality and all, that is your decision. for me it was still worth it because the movie is almost impossible to find anywhere.as of now, in 2012, it doesn't seem like you can find a decent DVD or Blu-ray copy of 'Charley and the Angel', this is the only one availiable. what a shame and how totally bizarre considering this is Fred MacMurray's last film for Disney. the studio executives obviously don't pay any attention to the archivist who work for them. this has gotta be one of the dumbest oversights the current studio has done concerning their legacy.
summary: One Of Disney's Best Live Action Films. Poor DVD Transfer Is The Problem

reviewText: STORY: During the Great Depression, Charley Appleby is a hard working small-town businessman. Since he started out so poor, he is relentless in his discipline to work hard and keep his business afloat. Even though he loves his family, he has neglected to spend enough quality time with them. His sons are especially hurt with him, and spend more time with other kids dads. One day his guardian angel shows up and lets him know his time is up, and Charley realizes he is leaving without making things right at home. But is his family too distant for him to do this? In the meantime he keeps trying to survive accidents intended to send him off. Will he mend things before he leaves? A series of mad-cap events involving his sons unknowingly transporting bootleg liquor, a prohibition era road house of ill repute, gangsters, police chases, a kidnapping, and more give him the chance to be a hero to his family.BEHIND THE SCENES: Released theatrically in 1973, this was the last acting role for Fred MacMurray before his retirement. He had appeared in a number of movies for Disney, who had pulled him out of his first retirement to appear in the 1959 comedy "The Shaggy Dog". Fred did a total of 7 movies for Disney, and later recieved the Disney Legend award in 1987, as the first-ever recipient of this now famous award.Cloris Leachman plays the part of Charley's  wife, Harry Morgan is great the angel, and Disney regular Kurt Russell pursues Charley's daughter against her fathers wishes. Great special effects of the angel and his powers. Long time Disney Studios set decorator/designer Emil Kuri gave the sets especially the general store an authentic period look. Accurate costuming and antique cars also lent to the period air. Most effective perhaps is the music score from Disney staff composer Buddy Baker, who incorporates many classic songs from the depression era. All the period touches blend together effectively for a very charming atmosphere, featuring a period in American history not covered enough in film. Walt Disney had passed away several years before this release, but he would have connected to the film having grown up in the depression. This movie aired later on the Disney television show in 1977, then first released on video in 1986. As of 2010 it has never been released again on video or DVD, making it quite rare. I recommend this movie if you have never seen it, its hilarious and touching at once, with some action and chase scenes, this period film is a little gem.
summary: Nice period film set in the depression

reviewText: Charley and the Angel from Disney Offers Fred MacMurray as a father of two Pre-high school boys that apparently need their father more than he recognizes. The Papa is more busy making a living than living. Cloris Leachman does reasonably as the prohibition era stay-at-home mom. Kurt Russell is touted as being a participant (daughter's boyfriend then elopement husband) but actually his role is relatively minor.Fred's (life) number comes up but snafus keep his ticket from actualy being punched.... Enter airborne but wingless angel Harry Morgan with folksy ways explaining that Fred has a second chance to be a good father and (maybe but unlikely) live/love happily ever after.Now what? Family going all which-a-ways, trouble in general, a deadline - literally....A simple non-attitude story blessed by those artists & writers that believe in simple blessings enhanced by simple special effects.'course... I like simple and uncomplicated. This is Saturday Morning Matinee at the Bijou fare for the primary schoolers with some real facts for the subtle educational input for which Unca Walt was so famous.In a single word : nice.
summary: Second Chance for Second Rated Disney fare
